repnme.cdata!:
India - Punjab Rural Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Punjab Rural Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project for India were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            information, education, and communication (IEC) and human
            resources development (HRD) is recognized as a critical
            function to deliver community driven rural water supply and
            sanitation services. Capacity building of gram panchayat
            water and sanitation committee (GPWSCs) is an ongoing
            activity to ensure sustainability and requires greater
            institutionalization. More specifically designed
            interventions are required in Punjab to ensure gender
            inclusiveness. Community empowerment, linked to technical
            backstopping by an engineering department, can provide an
            effective institutional structure for long term sustainability.

abstracts.cdata!:
In the light of the prevailing country
            practices and conditions and with the objective of aligning
            better with the country systems, there will be an extension
            of the timeline of the submission of the audits in the India
            portfolio from six to nine months for all active projects,
            starting with audit report due for FY2015. All future
            projects will continue to use the flexibility provided by
            OP/BO 10.00 in terms of determining the timing of the audit.
            This proposal to extend the date of submission of annual
            audit reports to nine months across the active India
            portfolio is being processed in response to India’s request
            dated 21-January-2015.
